The allele in the middle is "n". This can be seen by looking at the pattern of offspring in each case. In a three-point cross, the ratio of offspring genotypes should be 1:2:1, with the middle genotype being a recombination of the two outside genotypes.

In the first two cases, the middle genotype is UzN, which is a recombination of U and zn. This means that the middle allele must be "n".

In the next two cases, the middle genotype is uzn, which is a recombination of u and ZN. Again, the middle allele must be "n".

In the next two cases, the middle genotype is UzN, which is a recombination of U and zn. This means that the middle allele must be "n".

In the last two cases, the middle genotype is uZn, which is a recombination of u and zn. This means that the middle allele must be "n".

data.sampled:
I'm not quite sure what you mean by the "middle allele." However, based on the input and your output example, it looks like you want to find the most common allele in each genotype. In that case, you can use a Python list comprehension to iterate over the genotypes, split each genotype into its alleles, convert the alleles to lowercase, and count the occurrences of each allele. Finally, you can use the max() function to find the allele with the highest count. Here's some example code:

```
genotypes = [x.strip().split() for x in input().splitlines()]

def count_alleles(alleles):
    allele_counts = Counter(alleles)
    return allele_counts.most_common(1)[0][0]

results = [count_alleles(alleles) for alleles in genotypes]
print(*results, sep=", ")
```

In this code, we use a list comprehension to iterate over the genotypes input and pass each genotype's alleles to a function that counts the occurrences of each allele and returns the allele with the highest count. We then use the print() function with the separator argument to print the results, separated by commas and spaces.

Note that this solution assumes that each genotype is separated by a blank line, and that each allele is separated by a space within a genotype. If these assumptions don't hold for your input, you may need to modify the code accordingly.

Given the result of a three-point test cross, the allele in the middle is "a".

The genotype QAX represents a heterozygous individual with one dominant "Q" allele and one recessive "q" allele. Since the offspring count is 9, this individual must have been crossed with a homozygous recessive individual (qq), resulting in all of the offspring being heterozygous (Qa) and therefore having the allele "a".

Similarly, the genotype QaX represents a heterozygous individual with one dominant "Q" allele and one recessive "a" allele. Since the offspring count is 54, this individual must have been crossed with a homozygous dominant individual (QQ), resulting in 25% of the offspring being homozygous recessive (qq) and having the allele "q", and 50% of the offspring being heterozygous (Qa) and therefore having the allele "a".

The genotype QaX represents a heterozygous individual with one dominant "Q" allele and one recessive "a" allele. Since the offspring count is 27, this individual must have been crossed with an individual that is heterozygous (Qa), resulting in all of the offspring being heterozygous (Qa) and therefore having the allele "a".

The genotype qax represents a homozygous recessive individual (qq) with one copy of the "q" allele and one copy of another recessive allele (for example, "x"). Since the offspring count is 11, this individual must have been crossed with an individual that is heterozygous (Qa), resulting in 50% of the offspring being heterozygous (Qa) and therefore having the allele "a", and 50% of the offspring being homozygous recessive (qq) and having the allele "q".

The genotype QAk represents a heterozygous individual with one dominant "Q" allele and one recessive "k" allele. Since the offspring count is 63, this individual must have been crossed with an individual that is homozygous dominant (QQ), resulting in 25% of the offspring being homozygous recessive (qq) and having the allele "k", and 50% of the offspring being heterozygous (QAk) and therefore having the allele "a".

The genotype qAk represents a heterozygous individual with one dominant "Q" allele and one recessive "k" allele. Since the offspring count is 25, this individual must have been crossed with an individual that is heterozygous (QAk), resulting in all of the offspring being heterozygous (QAk) and therefore having the allele "a".

The genotype Qak represents a heterozygous individual with one dominant "Q" allele and one recessive "k" allele. Since the offspring count is 24, this individual must have been crossed with an individual that is homozygous recessive (qq), resulting in all of the offspring being heterozygous (Qak) and therefore having the allele "a".

The genotype qAK represents a homozygous recessive individual (qq) with one copy of the "q" allele and one copy of another recessive allele (for example, "K"). Since the offspring count is 13, this individual must have been crossed with an individual that is heterozygous (QAk), resulting in 50% of the offspring being heterozygous (QAk) and therefore having the allele "a", and 50% of the offspring being homozygous recessive (qq) and having the allele "q".
